Issues.Title: Discrepancy in TypeScript Inference Example in Angular Reactive Forms Documentation
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

While following the Angular guide on reactive forms, I noticed a discrepancy related to typed controls and TypeScript inference![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9cb335e5-72b1-40e7-8dd9-982537b08e25)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/62552d57-7728-4a09-a16d-7a41bf0d100b)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b6f47040-e84c-417f-9f16-28ee4bd3181a)
. The documentation suggests the following:

"It is possible to specify the type, instead of relying on inference. Consider a control that is initialized to null. Because the initial value is null, TypeScript will infer FormControl<null>, which is narrower than we want."

typescript
Copy code
const email = new FormControl(null);
email.setValue('angularrox@gmail.com'); // Error!
However, in my local environment, setting a value of any data type to email does not raise an error unless I explicitly declare the type as FormControl<null>, as shown below:

typescript
Copy code
const email = new FormControl<null>(null);
email.setValue('angularrox@gmail.com'); // Argument of type '"angularrox@gmail.com"' is not assignable to parameter of type 'null'.ts(2345)
Steps to Reproduce:

Initialize a form control with new FormControl(null).
Set a string value to the form control, e.g., email.setValue('angularrox@gmail.com').
Observe that no TypeScript error is raised.
Explicitly define the type as FormControl<null> and re-attempt setting a value.
Expected Behavior: An error should occur when setting a value that does not match the inferred type, as described in the guide.

Screenshots: (Attach screenshots here if relevant)

This appears to be either a documentation error or an inconsistency in type inference handling that may need clarification. Thank you for reviewing this!

Issues.Title: Feature Request: Component-Level Deferred Loading/Hydration Configuration in Angular
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

**Summary**: Add an option to define deferred loading (`@defer`) configuration at the component level, eliminating the need to wrap components in `@defer` blocks in the template.

**Background**: Angular's current implementation of deferred loading requires wrapping each component instance in an @defer block in the template. While this approach offers flexibility, it also introduces repetitive work in cases where a component always requires deferred loading or hydration. By defining this configuration directly at the component level, we can make templates cleaner, streamline the component setup, and reduce repetitive declarations.

**Problem**: For components that are consistently loaded or hydrated in a deferred manner, wrapping every instance in an @defer block becomes an additional task that could be avoided with a component-level setting. Such repetitive @defer blocks add to template complexity and can lead to more verbose code, particularly when applied to multiple components.

**Proposed Solution**: Introduce a component-level configuration option for deferred loading and hydration within the component. This approach would allow developers to specify that a component should always be deferred, without needing to wrap each instance in @defer in the template.

**Benefits**:

- **Cleaner Templates**: Templates become easier to read and maintain as @defer blocks are no longer needed in the template for components that consistently require deferred loading.
- **Reduced Redundancy**: Developers can specify deferred loading once at the component level instead of adding repetitive configuration in every usage.
- **Improved Developer Experience**: Simplifies the setup process for deferred components, making the feature more approachable and less error-prone.

**Conclusion**: A component-level deferred loading configuration would enhance Angular’s usability by reducing template complexity and making the deferred loading feature more streamlined. This aligns with Angular’s philosophy of reducing configuration burden in templates, leading to more maintainable and developer-friendly code.

### Proposed solution

I'm not certain what the best solution might be, but one possible approach that comes to mind is adding a defer configuration option directly to the component decorator.

```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-lazy-component',
  templateUrl: './lazy-component.component.html',
  defer: {},  // Component-level setting for deferred loading/hydration
})
export class LazyComponent { }
```

I understand that the Angular team is focused on reducing configuration within the component decorator. An alternative approach might be a `defer` function that accepts a configuration object as input, similar to functions like `afterNextRender` or `effect`.

Issues.Title: Replace leftover modules with exports in tests
Issues.Body:
Includes the following changes in an attempt to keep more tests working in the standalone migration:

### refactor(compiler-cli): broaden type of getPotentialImportsFor 
Currently the `getPotentialImportsFor` only accepts a `ClassDeclaration` as the context for generating an import, but that's not necessary because it doesn't require any class-specific information. These changes expand it to any `Node` so that it can be used when generating imports in testing declarations.

### fix(migrations): replace removed NgModules in tests with their exports 
In #57684 the standalone migration was changed so that it replaces any leftover modules with their `exports`, in an attempt to preserve more working code. These changes expand that logic to also cover tests since it's somewhat common internally to only import a component's module without having any references to the component.

Note that tests are a bit of a special case, because we don't have access to the template type checker, so instead we copy over all of the `exports` of that module.

### Is this a regression?

When the component's AfterViewInit was called, the host pseudo-class was correctly applied up to Angular 18. However, in Angular 19, it is no longer applied correctly. Issues.Title: 3rdpartylicenses.txt is being created in the wrong folder
Issues.Body:
The CLI build process creates the file _3rdpartylicenses.txt_ when the configuration is set to 'production' or includes `"extractLicenses": true`.

Prior to the new build system, _3rdpartylicenses.txt_ was saved to the root of the build output, typically _.\dist\my-project_.  This allowed it to be included by default in any distribution.

With the introduction of the new build system, the build process now saves the compiled output to _.\dist\my-project\browser_, but _3rdpartylicenses.txt_ is still being saved to _.\dist\my-project_, meaning that it is no longer included with the project output.  If it needs to be distributed as part of the application, it now needs an additional build step to copy it into the _browser_ subfolder.

**Expected behavior**
Under the new build system, _3rdpartylicenses.txt_ should be saved to the root of the same folder as the compiled output.

### Steps to reproduce

``` sh
ng new extract-licenses --style=css --skip-git=true
cd extract-licenses
ng build --configuration=production
dir .\dist\extract-licenses
```

## What is the current behavior?

When using `createRequestHandler` on Netlify edge function compatible request handler function I am forced to use `@ts-expect-error` directive currently:

```ts
import { AngularAppEngine, createRequestHandler } from '@angular/ssr'
const angularAppEngine = new AngularAppEngine()

// @ts-expect-error - createRequestHandler expects a function with single Request argument and doesn't allow context argument
export const reqHandler = createRequestHandler(async (request: Request, context: any) => {
  const result = await angularAppEngine.handle(request, context)
  return result || new Response('Not found', { status: 404 })
})
```

Issue Number: N/A

## What is the new behavior?

Don't need to use `@ts-expect-error` directive anymore.

```ts
import { AngularAppEngine, createRequestHandler } from '@angular/ssr'
const angularAppEngine = new AngularAppEngine()

export const reqHandler = createRequestHandler(async (request: Request, context: any) => {
  const result = await angularAppEngine.handle(request, context)
  return result || new Response('Not found', { status: 404 })
})
```

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

## Other information

From what I understand applying metadata done by `createRequestHandler` is used to recognize in dev mode that exported handle can be used to handle requests and falling back to "default" when it's not (and ignoring any customizations in `server.ts` file in dev mode because of it), so there doesn't seem to exist workaround the current type while still having access to second parameter?

Error: Schema validation failed with the following errors:

Issues.Title: Add style preprocessor option to disable deprecation warnings in Sass for V19
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

After updating **@angular** to v19, I’ve encountered a ton SCSS compiler deprecation warnings across many of my Angular projects. This issue occurs because the “_sass_” dependency in **@angular/build/package.json** was updated from “_1.77.6_” to “_1.80.6_”. As a temporary workaround, I reverted this dependency to “_1.77.6_” in the project’s node_modules directory, although this is - quite obvious - not ideal.

Ideally, we should remove deprecated SCSS code in our scss files and 3rd party dependencies (this is where it becomes a nightmare). However, as a temporary solution to silence these deprecation warnings and be relieved when running “_ng s_“, it would be helpful to pass a “**stylePreprocessorOptions**” (already exists) flag via “_angular.json_“ into the Sass compiler.

Please note that in Nuxt/Vite and Ember, disabling these deprecation warnings is already possible, see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67812380/disable-dart-sass-warnings-produced-by-external-theme-file) and [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/78997907/the-legacy-js-api-is-deprecated-and-will-be-removed-in-dart-sass-2-0-0).

### Proposed solution

Additional option in “angular.json". (Should default to false.)

```
"stylePreprocessorOptions": {
  "silenceDeprecations": true
},
```

This should result in passing the flag "--quiet-deps" to the sass compiler. How to silence this warnings internally can be learned here: https://sass-lang.com/documentation/breaking-changes/mixed-decls/#silencing-deprecations-in-dependencies

### Alternatives considered

Downgrade sass dep to “1.77.6“.

Issues.Title: feat(COMPONENT): add "disabledInteractive" input to "mat-menu-item"
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I want allow to set `disabledInteractive` to `button[mat-menu-item]` and `a[mat-menu-item]`.
Now `disabledInteractive` is available in `mat-button`, `mat-checkbox` , etc. It is used to make the appearance disabled but still allow tooltips etc. to be available.

### Use Case

I sometimes use menus when there is not enough space to display buttons. It is inconvenient that mat-menu-item can't do what mat-button can do.
